title: How to Make an Origami Star Box

steps.title: Pick out a square piece of origami paper.
steps.content: Pick out a square piece of origami paper. Pick a piece of origami paper that’s already cut into a small square so that it’s easier to fold. Try to use paper that’s made specifically for origami so that it’s lightweight and easy to work with. If you’d like to, choose a piece of paper with color on one side and no color on the other so you can follow the directions easily. [1] X Research source Classic origami is thin and lightweight, and you can find it at most craft supply stores. Using regular printer paper will be tough, since it’s harder to fold and doesn’t keep its shape as well.

steps.title: Flip the paper over so the colored side faces up.
steps.content: Flip the paper over so the colored side faces up. If you’re using a 2-sided origami paper, flip it over so that the non-colored side is down and the colored side faces you. Angle the paper so it’s in a diamond shape to start with in front of you. [2] X Research source It may help to work near a flat surface, like a table or countertop, so you can rest the paper on something while you work.

steps.title: Fold the paper in half diagonally.
steps.content: Fold the paper in half diagonally. Grab the top point of the diamond and fold it down to meet the bottom point of the diamond. Press down on the fold to crease the paper, but leave the paper on the table to make your next fold. [3] X Research source This will make a cute, tiny triangle out of your paper.

steps.title: Fold the left corner over to the right corner.
steps.content: Fold the left corner over to the right corner. Grab the left corner of the triangle and bring it over to the right corner, folding the small triangle you made in half. Press down on the fold to crease it into place, and leave your paper on the table. [4] X Research source This fold will make an even cuter and tinier triangle.

steps.title: Lift the corner of the paper up to separate the layers.
steps.content: Lift the corner of the paper up to separate the layers. Keeping the paper folded into a triangle, lift up the first layer to open up the corners. This will create a small opening in the flap that you can hold open with your fingers. [5] X Research source Make sure you’re only working with the top 2 layers of paper, and you’re leaving the bottom 2 layers of paper alone.

steps.title: Press the corner down to flatten it into a square.
steps.content: Press the corner down to flatten it into a square. Still working with only the one flap that you opened up, press it down in the center to flatten it out. Crease the edges with your fingers to make a small square out of half the paper, with the pointed triangle flip still underneath it. [6] X Research source This will make an abstract shape with a square on top and a triangle on the bottom.

steps.title: Turn the paper over and lift the left flap up.
steps.content: Turn the paper over and lift the left flap up. Grab your origami paper and flip it over so that the shape is resting on top of the small square part. Keep the triangle portion of the paper on top so you can work with it next. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Open the flap and push it downwards to flatten it.
steps.content: Open the flap and push it downwards to flatten it. Taking the triangle flap that you still have, open it up and push it downward just like you did with the other one. This will create a small square out of your paper that you can work with. [8] X Research source Be sure you’re creasing the paper really well with your fingers on each fold you make. This will ensure that your box stays intact when you open it up. The square that you end up with is also called a “square base.”

steps.title: Fold the left and right corners in toward the center.
steps.content: Fold the left and right corners in toward the center. Making sure the opening of the square is pointed downward, fold the left and right flaps in. Meet the corners in the center of the square to create 2 small triangles on either side. [9] X Research source Make sure your paper looks symmetrical at this point so you know you’re folding each side evenly.

steps.title: Open the left flap and press down to squash fold it.
steps.content: Open the left flap and press down to squash fold it. Pull the left flap up and then press down on the bottom part, squashing it into a fold. Crease the edges with your fingers to hold them down. [10] X Research source The left flap should have a small triangle at the bottom and then be open at the top.

steps.title: Do the same thing to the right flap.
steps.content: Do the same thing to the right flap. Lift up the right flap and press down on the bottom part to make a squash fold. Again, use your fingers to crease the edges and hold them in their shape. [11] X Research source Both flaps should be folded the same way, so your paper should be symmetrical at this point. If it isn’t, go back 1 step and try again.

steps.title: Turn the paper over and repeat on the other side.
steps.content: Turn the paper over and repeat on the other side. Flip your square of paper over and fold the left and right corners in toward the center. Pull the left flap up and squash fold it, then pull the right flap up and squash fold it. Make sure you crease the paper every time you fold to hold your box in place. [12] X Research source Your origami paper won’t be square anymore, but it won’t quite be triangular, either.

steps.title: Fold the left flap over to the right.
steps.content: Fold the left flap over to the right. Making sure the opening of your paper still faces downard, grab the left flap and fold it over to the right. This should expose a solid piece of paper without any folds or creases in it that hides the folds you just made. [13] X Research source Your paper still won’t look like a square, but it will be closer to its original shape than what it just was.

steps.title: Fold both sides in toward the center.
steps.content: Fold both sides in toward the center. Keeping the paper in the same position, grab the right and left corners and fold them in until they meet in the center. The bottom part of the paper will make a pointed triangle. [14] X Research source At this point, you’re starting to make the base of the box.

steps.title: Flip the paper over and repeat on the other side.
steps.content: Flip the paper over and repeat on the other side. Turn your paper over so you see the other side of the exposed paper without any folds. Now, bring the right and left corners in toward the center to make a pointed triangle base. Your entire paper will look like an ice cream cone with a geometric scoop of ice cream on the top. [15] X Research source The top portion of the paper will eventually turn into the flat base of the box.

steps.title: Crease the top layer upwards to make a small triangle.
steps.content: Crease the top layer upwards to make a small triangle. Keeping your paper neatly situated, grab the bottom part of the top layer (the point of the ice cream cone). Lift this flap up until it hits the point that it can’t fold anymore, then press down on the fold to crease it into place. [16] X Research source You’re almost there! You only have a few more steps until you can unfold your box.

steps.title: Repeat the last step for the 3 other sides of the paper.
steps.content: Repeat the last step for the 3 other sides of the paper. Flip the flap over to the left to reveal another side of the origami paper. Fold the point upward to make a triangle on top just like you did in the last step. Flip the flap over and make a triangle on top 2 more times until your paper looks like it has a 4-point star in the center. [17] X Research source At this point, you might be able to see the box shape come into formation.

steps.title: Open your box from the top and flatten out the sides.
steps.content: Open your box from the top and flatten out the sides. Flip your paper over until the opening faces upwards. Using your fingers, carefully pull the sides apart until they’re flat, with the bottom part of the box flat on the table. Smooth out any creases to watch your box unfold before your very eyes! [18] X Research source To make sure the bottom of the box is completely flat, press it down on the table and run your fingers over the bottom to smooth it out.

steps.title: Use acrylic paint to paint the box a different color.
steps.content: Use acrylic paint to paint the box a different color. If you aren’t quite happy with how your star box looks, pick out an acrylic paint color and use a paint brush to give it an extra decoration. Try painting the sides one color and the bottom part another for a cool, contrasting effect. [19] X Research source You can find acrylic paint at most craft stores. Try pairing red and pink, green and yellow, or blue and purple.

steps.title: Glue rhinestones to the outer triangles of the box.
steps.content: Glue rhinestones to the outer triangles of the box. Grab a hot glue gun and wait for it to warm up. Add 5 to 6 small dots of hot glue on the outer edges of the box, then use small fake rhinestones to decorate the edges. You can do this to all 4 of the outer triangles, or keep it fancy by just decorating one. [20] X Research source Use silver rhinestones for a diamond look, or go with brightly colored ones for an eye-catching design.

steps.title: Make your star box shine with some glitter glue.
steps.content: Make your star box shine with some glitter glue. Hold the point of a glitter glue pen up to your box and gently squeeze it to make the glue come out. Use the glitter glue to add stars, polka dots, or even your name to the outside of your star box. Don’t forget to let the glue dry before you start putting things into your box! [21] X Research source Try picking out your favorite color of glitter glue to personalize the box even more. If you don’t have glitter glue, use liquid school glue to make a design on the box, then sprinkle loose glitter on top of it. Be careful with this method, as it can get a little messy.

steps.title: Store candy, paper clips, earrings, or beads in your star box.
steps.content: Store candy, paper clips, earrings, or beads in your star box. Now that your box is done, you can keep it on your desk or dresser to store small items that might get lost. You can keep your jewelry organized, declutter your workspace, or hold craft supplies with your beautiful origami box. [22] X Research source Try making a few star boxes in different colors to decorate your room and organize your area.
